8638a2b7a48592cfa3be5b85ac45dcbe.text:
Get site configuration. This is the configuration defined in the YAML files in the /sites folder as of TYPO3 9. Some of the settings can also be set via the "Sites" page module.

In the context of a MiddleWare, the site may not be parsed/loaded yet. In this case the $request can be passed from the MiddleWare to get the site.

$config = \nn\t3::Settings()->getSiteConfig();
$config = \nn\t3::Settings()->getSiteConfig( $request );

@return array

0a069efbc37e6db97fbde9abb9334cb9.text:
Get current (FIRST) StoragePid for the current plugin. Stored in the TypoScript setup of the extension under plugin.tx_extname.persistence.storagePid or in the FlexForm of the plugin on the respective page.

IMPORTANT: Merge with selected StoragePID from the FlexForm only happens if $extName is left blank.

\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePid(); // 123
\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePid('nnsite'); // 466

@return string

177b7f8e033a0817e83d72683a8b0050.text:
Get ALL storagePids for the current plugin. Stored as a comma-separated list in the extension's TypoScript setup at. plugin.tx_extname.persistence.storagePid or in the FlexForm of the plugin on the respective page.

IMPORTANT: Merge with selected StoragePID from the FlexForm only happens if $extName is left blank.

\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePids(); // [123, 466]
\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePids('nnsite'); // [123, 466]

Get the child PageUids as well? true takes the value for "recursive" from the FlexForm or from the TypoScript of the extension from plugin.tx_extname.persistence.recursive

\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePids(true); // [123, 466, 124, 467, 468]
\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePids('nnsite', true); // [123, 466, 124, 467, 468]

Alternatively, a numeric value can be passed for the depth / recursion. can be passed.

\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePids(2); // [123, 466, 124, 467, 468]
\nn\t3::Settings()->getStoragePids('nnsite', 2); // [123, 466, 124, 467, 468]

@return array

Get the basic configuration for the TCA. These are the fields like hidden, starttime etc. which are always the same for (almost) all tables.

'columns' => \nn\t3::TCA()->createConfig(

    ['sys_language_uid', 'l10n_parent', 'l10n_source', 'l10n_diffsource', 'hidden', 'cruser_id', 'pid', 'crdate', 'tstamp', 'sorting', 'starttime', 'endtime', 'fe_group'],

)

8d5a4b6034e2da4487b7681a003f19fc.text:
Get default configuration for various typical types in TCA Serves as a kind of alias to write the most frequently used config arrays faster and shorter. and shorter

\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'text' ); // => ['type'=>'text', 'rows'=>2, ...]
\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'rte' ); // => ['type'=>'text', 'enableRichtext'=>'true', ...]
\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'color' ); // => ['type'=>'input', 'renderType'=>'colorpicker', ...]
\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'fal', 'image' ); // => ['type'=>'input', 'renderType'=>'colorpicker', ...]

Default configurations can be easily overridden/extended:

\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'text', ['rows'=>5] ); // => ['type'=>'text', 'rows'=>5, ...]

For each type, the most frequently overridden value in the config array can also be by passing a fixed value instead of an override array:

\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'text', 10 ); // => ['rows'=>10, ...]
\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'rte', 'myRteConfig' ); // => ['richtextConfiguration'=>'myRteConfig', ...]
\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'color', '#ff6600' ); // => ['default'=>'#ff6600', ...]
\nn\t3::TCA()->getConfigForType( 'fal', 'image' ); // => [ config for the field with key `image` ]

@return array

Overwrite a configuration of the TCA, e.g. to override a mask field with a custom renderType. or to change core settings in the TCA on the pages or tt_content tables.

The following example sets/overwrites the config array in the TCA at:

$GLOBALS['TCA']['tt_content']['columns']['mycol']['config'][...]
\nn\t3::TCA()->setConfig('tt_content.columns.mycol', [
    'renderType' => 'nnsiteIconCollection',
    'iconconfig' => 'tx_nnsite.iconcollection',
]);

See also \nn\t3::TCA()->setContentConfig() for a short version of this method when dealing with the table tt_content and \nn\t3::TCA()->setPagesConfig() for the table pages

9c003c53e5dbab9384f16dae863ac19b.text:
Various methods for parsing PHP source code and comments in the Source Code (Annotations). Objective: to create automated documentation from the comments in the PHP code.

Examples of use including rendering of the template

In the controller with rendering by fluid:

$path = \nn\t3::Environment()->extPath('myext') . 'Classes/Utilities/';
$doc = \Nng\Nnhelpers\DocumentationHelper::parseFolder( $path );
$this->view->assign('doc', $doc);

Generating the Typo3 / Sphinx ReST doc via a custom fluid template:

$path = \nn\t3::Environment()->extPath('myext') . 'Classes/Utilities/';
$doc = \Nng\Nnhelpers\DocumentationHelper::parseFolder( $path );

foreach ($doc as $className=>$infos) {
  $rendering = $nn\t3::Template()->render(
    'EXT:myext/Resources/Private/Backend/Templates/Documentation/ClassTemplate.html', [
      'infos' => $infos
    ]
  );

  $filename = $infos['fileName'] . '.rst';
  $file = \nn\t3::File()->absPath('EXT:myext/Documentation/Utilities/Classes/' . $filename);
  $result = file_put_contents( $file, $rendering );
}

d71395c51b784a966d20adc47c902067.text:
The script helps convert and parse JavaScript object strings into an array.

$data = \Nng\Nnhelpers\JsonHelper::decode( "{title:'Test', cat:[2,3,4]}" );
print_r($data);

The helper allows to use the JavaScript object notation in TypoScript and convert it to an array via the {nnt3:parse.json()} ViewHelper. This is handy if, for example, slider configurations or other JavaScript objects should be defined in TypoScript to be used later in JavaScript.

Another application example: You want to use the "normal" JS syntax in a .json file instead of the JSON syntax. Let's look at an example. This text was written to a text file and is to be parsed by PHP:

// Contents of a text file.
{
    example: ['one', 'two', 'three']
}

PHP would report an error in this example with json_decode(): The string contains comments, wraps and the keys and values are not enclosed in double quotes. The JsonHelper or the ViewHelper $jsonHelper->decode() can convert it without any problems.

This is how you could define a JS object in the TypoScript setup:

// Content in TS setup.
my_conf.data (
  {
     dots: true,
     sizes: [1, 2, 3]
  }
)

The mixture is a bit irritating: my_conf.data (...) opens a section for multiline code in TypoScript. Between the (...) there is a "normal" JavaScript object. This can be easily used as an array in the Fluid template:

{nnt3:ts.setup(path:'my_conf.data')->f:variable(name:'myConfig')}
{myConfig->nnt3:parse.json()->f:debug()}

Or append as a data attribute to an element to parse it later via JavaScript:

{nnt3:ts.setup(path:'my_conf.data')->f:variable(name:'myConfig')}

...

This script is mostly based on the work of https://bit.ly/3eZuNu2 and has been has been optimized for PHP 7+ by us.

All credit to that direction please.

ce872191eb3b86a46a11682df7d60d60.text:
Converts a JS object string into an array.

$data = \Nng\Nnhelpers\JsonHelper::decode( "{title:'Test', cat:[2,3,4]}" );

The PHP function json_decode() only works with JSON syntax: {"key": "value"}. In JSON neither line breaks nor comments are allowed. This function can also be used to parse strings in JavaScript notation.

e7fa18472528393a6580a93e14dfe5e2.text:
Translation management via Deep-L.

For this function to be usable, a Deep-L Api key must be stored in the extension manager of nnhelpers The key is free of charge and allows the translation of 500,000 characters per month.

// Activate translator
$translationHelper = \nn\t3::injectClass( \Nng\Nnhelpers\Helpers\TranslationHelper::class );

// allow translation via Deep-L
$translationHelper->setEnableApi( true );
// set target language
$translationHelper->setTargetLanguage( 'EN' );

// Allow max. Number of translations allowed (for debugging purposes)
$translationHelper->setMaxTranslations( 2 );

// Path where to store / cache the l18n files
$translationHelper->setL18nFolderpath( 'EXT:nnhelpers/Resources/Private/Language/' );

// start translation
$text = $translationHelper->translate('my.example.key', 'This is the text to translate');

d767ca6998e97471bb32b88c9511d5e3.text:

$translationHelper->createKeyHash( '12345' );

@return string

22b498a63972c78dddb12879de903730.text:
Creates a unique hash / checksum from the text. The passed text is always the base language. If the text changes in the base language, the method returns a different checksum. This detects when a text needs to be retranslated. Pure changes to whitespaces and tags are ignored.

$translationHelper->createKeyHash( '12345' );
$translationHelper->createKeyHash( ['my', 'key', 'array'] );

@return string
